We show that the category of Hilbert spaces and linear operators has an initial object, which is the space of complex-valued functions on the real line. This result is a categorical version of the celebrated spectral theorem for normal operators. We use this result to define a notion of “Hilbert space” in a purely categorical way, without presupposing any analytical structure. This has applications to the foundations of quantum theory and to the theory of topological Markov chains.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that have been the subject of intense study for over a century. Despite this, the origin of the Myxozoa remains elusive, and the group has been classified in a variety of ways. Here, we present a genomic and transcriptomic analysis of two myxozoans and a cnidarian parasite, and we show that the Myxozoa are a sister group to the cnidarians. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides a glimpse into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (PsycINFO Database Record

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is one of the main factors that contribute to the severity of the disease and the high mortality rate of COVID-19. In this study, we identified a mechanism by which SARS-CoV-2, the causative agent of COVID-19, is able to block nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes. Our results show that SARS-CoV-2 uses a viral accessory protein, Orf6, to block nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2. Our findings provide a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the antiviral action of IFN and may lead to the development of new strategies to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by the middle of the 21st century, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 70% to meet this demand. We show that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase almost everywhere in the world, and that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase in the major maize-exporting countries. These results highlight the importance of breeding for heat tolerance, and they underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance, especially in the major maize-exporting countries.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of quantifying diet composition at the species level. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of wild and domestic large mammals in semiarid African savanna. Our results show that, despite being similar in body size and digestive physiology, these species differed in their proportional grass consumption, their dietary overlap, and their dietary composition. These differences were often greater than the differences between species in body size and digestive physiology. Our results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that large mammal diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our approach may be used to quantify diet composition in other systems. (Less)

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Many businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Many businesses plan to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but many anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most common forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. Our observations of the size distribution of floating plastic debris point at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The cosmic ray exposure ages of large presolar silicon carbide grains from the Murchison CM2 meteorite are presented. The grains have ages of <300 Ma and >1 Ga, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains and longer than expected for grains in the interstellar medium. The grains were part of aggregates in the interstellar medium, and the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium. The grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago, which is an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. The grains are part of a growing body of evidence that the early solar system was influenced by an enhanced star formation episode. The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to provide energy to the mother is one of the most important traits in nature. We show that the ability to provide energy to the mother is a strong predictor of reproductive output, and that this effect is not explained by resource availability.

In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a phase II clinical trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study provides a proof of concept for the use of VX-765 in a mouse model of MSA, a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the interface between the circulatory system and the tissues of the body. It is the primary regulator of vascular function and is the target of many diseases. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are highly specialized to control vascular function. The endothelium is able to integrate and respond to multiple lines of information, and to coordinate vascular function and inflammation. Here, we show that the endothelium is organized into a network of cells that is highly efficient in the transmission of information. The network is small-world, which means that it is both efficient at transmitting information locally and globally. The network is also highly synchronizable, which means that it is able to respond to changes in the environment rapidly. These findings have implications for understanding the function of the endothelium and for developing new therapies for cardiovascular diseases.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of public health surveillance signals, as well as many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. These are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the pore of K+ channels, and it is the site of ion conduction. The selectivity filter is also the site of the activation gate, which is responsible for the opening of the channel. We have shown that the selectivity filter can be used as a structural element for the functional regulation of the channel.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to be important for the health of the host. However, the mechanisms by which the microbiome regulates the host are poorly understood. In this study, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate the microbiome. We find that anaerobic fungi synthesize a variety of natural products, including antibiotics, that could be used to regulate the microbiome. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi are important contributors to the microbiome and that natural products could be used to manipulate the microbiome. This work provides a foundation for future studies to investigate the role of natural products in the microbiome.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, yet the influence of personality traits on social rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social behavior and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. The ability to design and manufacture mechanical structures with desired behaviors is of great importance for the development of functional devices. However, the design of such structures is often limited by the availability of materials and the knowledge of mechanical behaviors. Here, we develop a synthesis strategy that can design and manufacture composite structures with desired behaviors. The strategy is based on the inverse design of composite structures that are composed of multiple materials with distinct mechanical properties. The synthesized structures are then manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, which is a process that allows the use of different elastomers with distinct mechanical properties. The structures are then assembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex behaviors. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design and manufacture functional devices with desired behaviors. This work can provide a new paradigm for the design and manufacture of functional devices.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development and aging. In this study, we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in the human erythroid system and that it can reverse the adult hemoglobin pattern toward a more fetal-like expression. This finding has implications for the understanding of the role of the hemoglobin system in the regulation of development and aging.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of resistance to treatment is a major obstacle to successful treatment. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, in cancer cells. This resistance is mediated by the activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In addition, we found that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models. These findings provide a rationale for the development of combination therapies targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway and ferroptosis induction in cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) and promote vascular remodeling. Our findings provide a mechanistic explanation for the association of LCCBs with heart failure and suggest that the use of LCCBs should be limited in patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was not successful in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird species. Instead, the policy accelerated the decline of these species, partly due to the loss of older forests to fire on federal land and continued clearcutting elsewhere. Our results highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this work, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The results of this work are expected to contribute to the development of new antibiotics and to the improvement of the current treatment of infections caused by antibiotic-resistant pathogens. We introduce a new deep convolutional neural network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The network architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is able to achieve state-of-the-art results in practice. The code is available at https://github.com/yannickdelange/dilated-cnn.

The evolution of the Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is a classic example of the effects of environmental change on biological adaptation. The species flock is endemic to Lake Malawi, and the evolution of the species is thought to be driven by the availability of new ecological niches. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind, 1.3-My record of hydroclimate variability from Lake Malawi, East Africa. The record shows that the evolution of the species flock was influenced by the changing hydroclimate, and the species adapted to the changing conditions. The evolution of the species flock is a classic example of the effects of environmental change on biological adaptation. The record also shows that the evolution of the species flock was not the only biological adaptation to the changing hydroclimate, and that the changing hydroclimate was influenced by the evolution of the species flock. This study demonstrates the importance of understanding the full context of biological and environmental change to understand the processes that drive biological evolution. (Less)

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This practice is associated with reduced sleep duration and quality, and with adverse consequences on general health. The mechanisms underlying the negative impact of electronic devices on sleep are not well understood. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device suppresses melatonin and reduces sleepiness, and that this effect is associated with a delayed circadian clock and reduced alertness the following morning. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. They also provide a framework for understanding the impact of other artificial-light sources on sleep. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Younger Dryas cooling is one of the most enigmatic events in the last 10,000 y. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the magnetic grains and microspherules are of terrestrial origin, and that the YDB spherules are derived from a source in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. The 187Os/188Os ratios of the magnetic grains and microspherules are similar to average upper continental crust, and the 187Os/188Os ratios of the spherules are often low, but Os in these objects is likely terrestrially derived. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the spherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmune diseases is still unclear. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. We also show that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. These findings provide a better understanding of the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to trace the evolution of beetles and to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification. Our analyses resolved previously controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, plant cell wall-degrading enzymes (PCWDEs) obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of an arsenal of PCWDEs encoded in their genomes. Beetle diversity thus appears to have resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding PCWDEs. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Less)

We report the results of a large-scale experiment in which participants were asked to construct paper planes and to learn from the planes constructed by others. We show that the size of the population of models that participants can learn from has no effect on the performance of the planes they construct. However, the size of the population does affect the variation in performance that participants have access to, and this variation is important for the evolution of better-adapted planes.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas APOE E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the phagocytic capacity of astrocytes that is highly dependent on APOE isoform. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km, which is the largest and densest part of the planet. It is believed to have formed by the solidification of a molten iron core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much more likely than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase, which is the stable phase of iron at the core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our findings have implications for the origin of the inner core and the evolution of the core. They also provide a new perspective for understanding the solidification of other materials. Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use are well known, the effects of acute marijuana use on the brain are less understood. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), is reduced in marijuana abusers. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, as well as with increased addiction severity and craving. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s processing of language is a central focus of neuroscience. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks also predict the brain’s processing of language. This suggests that the brain’s language system is tuned to the predictions of these networks, and that the brain’s processing of language is fundamentally predictive in nature.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major breakthrough in machine learning, but it is still a black box. We show that the instability of DL is due to the fact that the algorithms used to train DL models are not well conditioned. We introduce a new algorithm that is stable and can be used to train stable DL models.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act in time, the spread of misinformation, and the inability of people to understand exponential growth. In this paper, we show that the latter factor is not only a contributing factor but, in fact, the main cause of the former two. We discuss the classic experiment that is often cited as evidence for the former factor, but that, in hindsight, is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and it is still a major public health problem in many parts of the world. The causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been studied for decades, and the current understanding of the disease is based on this organism. However, the genome of the causative agent has been sequenced only recently, and it is still not known whether it is the same as the genome of the leprosy bacilli that have been studied for decades. Here, we report the genome sequence of a leprosy pathogen that has been studied for many years but has not been studied in depth. We show that the two leprosy pathogens are remarkably conserved and that they are still able to cause similar diseases. This study provides a better understanding of the evolution of the leprosy pathogens and may lead to the development of new therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The dynamics of entanglement and entropy in isolated quantum systems is a central topic of current research. However, the exact computation of these quantities is a formidable task, even in the simplest cases. Here, we show that the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics, complemented with integrability-based knowledge of the steady state and its excitations, leads to a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5 million people worldwide. The development of a vaccine is the most effective way to control the pandemic. We have developed a vaccine candidate, COVI-VAC, that is based on a temperature-sensitive live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 strain. This vaccine candidate is easy to manufacture, has a large safety margin, and is highly protective.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) was characterized by recurrent epidemics and high mortality. The vector of the disease was unknown, and the impact of the disease on the population was not well understood. We developed a mathematical model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We found that the model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of human behavior in the spread of infectious diseases.

The evolution of the brain is one of the most important topics in biology. It is also one of the most difficult to study because of the lack of direct evidence. In this study, we use the largest dataset of its kind to reconstruct the evolution of brain size in amniotes, a group that includes birds and mammals. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The HSP90 chaperone family is involved in a wide range of cellular processes, including the regulation of metabolism. In this study, we show that TRAP1, a member of the HSP90 family, is involved in the regulation of metabolism and tumorigenesis.

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements that are responsible for many cellular processes. They are dynamic structures that can be either assembled or disassembled. The latter process is essential for the disassembly of the cytoskeleton, which is required for the reorganization of the cytoskeleton and the cell as a whole. The cofilin family of proteins is the main regulator of actin filament disassembly. We show that the action of cofilin is enhanced by mechanical stress. We also show that the mechanical stress can be exerted by the actin filaments themselves, which are held between two anchoring points. This leads to a torque that enhances the action of cofilin. This is a new mechanism that could be used by other proteins to exert mechanical stress on their targets.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in soft drinks and other foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in reward-related regions and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may be a stronger stimulus for feeding behavior. This may have important implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and diabetes.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, which allowed us to study the genetic history of Madagascar in a way that was not possible before. We find that Madagascar was settled by a Bantu and Austronesian population, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement happened recently, and the genetic structure is the result of a combination of admixture and demographic growth. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. Our results provide a better understanding of the history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean region. They also provide a framework for the study of the genetic history of other islands and the Indian Ocean region. This is a large-scale experiment, with more than 800,000 people, and the results are robust to a number of different analyses. The results suggest that people are influenced by the emotions of others, and that this influence is mediated by the content of the posts. The ribosome is the central enzyme of protein synthesis, and the mRNA sequences that direct protein synthesis are modified in many ways. In this work, we show that the presence of a single pseudouridine (Ψ) in an mRNA codon can have a significant impact on the rate of protein synthesis. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can alter the rate of protein synthesis and that this can be a consequence of the ribosome encountering Ψ. Our findings have implications for the function of Ψ in mRNA, and for the design of new antibiotics. (Show more)

This study shows that feeling that the things one does in life are worthwhile is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social engagement, and time use. These findings have implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of aquatic life is a major theme in biology, but the extent to which the aquatic lifestyle constrains the evolution of body size is not well understood. We use a model of the energetic costs and benefits of living in water to show that the aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades. This model provides a mechanistic explanation for the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals and suggests that the aquatic lifestyle may be a major driver of the evolution of body size in other aquatic organisms.

The common cold is the most common disease worldwide, and rhinovirus is the main cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication has been studied in cell culture, but the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here, we show that mouse airway cells infected with mouse-adapted rhinovirus 1B exhibit a striking enrichment in expression of antiviral defense response genes at 37 °C relative to 33 °C, which correlates with higher expression levels of type I and type III IFN genes and IFN-stimulated genes at 37 °C. These findings demonstrate that in mouse airway cells, rhinovirus replicates preferentially at nasal cavity temperature due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These results have implications for the development of rhinovirus vaccines and antiviral therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in their surroundings. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to detect the presence of surfaces. This mechanochemical sensing mechanism is essential for the regulation of surface-induced gene expression and virulence. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the evolution of sensing systems in bacteria and the regulation of surface-induced gene expression in pathogenic bacteria.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface water and their impact on aquatic biodiversity. Our results show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. The virus has also spread to animals, including wildlife, and the potential for spillback into humans is a major concern. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living deer, and the identification of multiple lineages. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic, and highlight the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This is a call to action for the scientific community to work together to address this global health threat. (Less)

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the immune response in AD is often attributed to sustained microglial activation in response to Aβ deposits and cell death. Here, we show that neurons, which are the primary cell type in the brain responsible for Aβ production, are also the source of an immune response. This neuron-derived inflammatory profile is unique to Aβ-burdened neurons, and it correlates with the extent of microglial activation and mobilization. We also demonstrate that the human brain contains a neuron-specific inflammatory response, which may precede the formation of Aβ plaques and tau tangles. Thus, we propose that the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ may be a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. This study provides a new perspective on the role of the immune system in AD, and it may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. It is a main source of protein for a large part of the world’s population. The question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. We present a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was practiced there as early as the fourth century B.C.E. This is the earliest known evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in the world. We further show that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study has important implications for the history of animal domestication and for the evolution of the human–animal relationship. (Less)

The folding of proteins is a major unsolved problem in biology. The results reported here are a contribution to the understanding of protein folding. They are based on a combination of methods that provide a detailed picture of the folding process of a large protein.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a key mechanism for the control of gene expression in bacteria. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap from Np4-capped RNAs is also active on Np4-capped transcripts, and that it preferentially removes the cap from Np4-capped RNAs. This finding has implications for the control of gene expression during stress, as well as for the design of new antibiotics. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with a high mortality rate. Although there are several therapeutic strategies for sepsis, there is no specific treatment that can restore immune function. In this study, we demonstrated that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is a promising therapeutic strategy for sepsis.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers. Our analysis highlights the importance of the global marine biomass for the functioning of the ecosystem and the need for a better understanding of the biomass of wild marine species. Finally, we highlight the importance of the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. This work is a first step toward a better understanding of the biomass of the biosphere.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) that is continuous in contrast to all known models of SOC. We show that our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is used in a variety of applications, including in electronics, optics, and photonics. However, diamond is brittle and is prone to cracking under mechanical stress. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, i.e., its bandgap can be closed, without any instability of the crystal structure. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, i.e., its bandgap can be opened, without any instability of the crystal structure. These findings open up opportunities for tailoring the properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

The discovery of antifungal peptides is a recent and exciting development in the field of plant defense. These peptides are of great interest for the development of new, environmentally friendly, and sustainable plant protection products. However, the mode of action of these peptides is still poorly understood. Here, we report the structure and mode of action of a unique antifungal peptide, which is expressed in the nodules of a model legume, and demonstrate its potential as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This work provides a foundation for the development of this class of peptides as a sustainable alternative to synthetic fungicides. (Less)

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between male and female reproductive tracts. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. Multiple seminal fluid proteins initially associate with sperm, but most become undetectable after sperm are stored. Female-derived proteins also begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome following 4 d of storage in the female reproductive tract. Female-derived proteins that associate with sperm are enriched for processes associated with energy metabolism, suggesting that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (PsycINFO Database Record

The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large, multidomain protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the surface of platelets. The binding reaction is triggered, in part, by alterations in flow. We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease (VWD), a disorder of VWF function. The mechanism also provides a target for the treatment of VWD.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that live in and on humans, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which can be used to study the human virome and its impact on human health. The database is publicly available and can be used to study the human virome and its impact on human health.

The aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) process is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the ACI process is very complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. The main reason is that the ACI process is very difficult to be observed. In this study, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe the aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously. The observations of the dual-FOV HSRL are used to investigate the ACI process. The results show that the ACI process is more complicated than expected. The aerosol loading has no discernible effect on the liquid water path, but it has a significant effect on the cloud droplet number concentration and effective radius. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This study is expected to provide a new way to observe the ACI process. The temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past is of great importance for understanding the evolution of life on Earth. Ion channels are the main ion-conducting proteins in cells and are important for the normal function of the nervous system and the heart. Ion channels are also the targets of drugs and are the focus of many studies. In this study, we found that the large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel has a closed state-dependent C-type inactivation that is not found in other K+ channels.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with an estimated 409,000 deaths in 2015. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a variety of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses a key adhesin, EBA175, to alter the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of malaria invasion, suggesting that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate entry. This finding has implications for the development of new antimalarial drugs. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum devices, and energy storage. However, it is brittle and difficult to process. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, and that its electronic bandgap can be fully closed. This opens up opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

The impact of ambient humidity on the severity of influenza virus infection is a long-standing and controversial issue. In this study, we show that housing mice in low humidity increases the severity of influenza virus infection. We also show that this effect is mediated, at least in part, by impaired host defense against influenza infection, reduced tissue repair, and caspase-dependent pathology. Our findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the impact of ambient humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. These results also suggest that humidity may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza severity. Our study may also have implications for the design of influenza vaccines and antiviral therapies. (Show more)

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures in a left-corner parser, starting with the simplest elements and gradually adding more complex ones. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the construction of syntactic structures increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This pattern of activity is consistent with a left-corner parser, which is able to merge words into phrases without losing information about the structure of the sentence. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This is the first study to show that the brain’s activity during language processing varies with the complexity of the linguistic objects it is processing. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the neural basis of language and for the design of language-based brain-computer interfaces.

Wnt signaling is a major pathway in development, and the two vertebrate forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are functionally redundant. We show that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which may be used to control the responsiveness of the pathway in different tissues. This is an example of a subtle difference that may be important for the function of redundant genes.

The brain is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the function of any one part without considering the function of the entire system. Here we show that a specific part of the brain, the lateral hypothalamus, is involved in the development of overeating in response to electrical stimulation. We also show that this part of the brain is part of a larger circuit that promotes overeating.

The ability of plants to fix nitrogen (N2-fixation) is a key ecosystem service, but the contribution of N2-fixation to global food security is threatened by the loss of soil N2-fixing bacteria. In this work, we developed a system for the control of the symbiotic interaction between plants and bacteria, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a platform for the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the host plant can control the timing and location of the symbiotic interaction. This work is a step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species.
