We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our results suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

The spider is a model organism for studying the evolution of sensory systems and the development of new sensors. Here, we show that the spider can outsource its hearing to its web, which acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna. The web is able to detect the motion of air particles, which is the fundamental property of hearing. The spider can also supersize its acoustic sensor by outsourcing it to its web, which is a unique feature for studying the evolution of sensory systems.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil fuels and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic with no approved vaccine. We report the design, construction, and characterization of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that is well-suited for large-scale production and elicits high-affinity antibodies. This protein can be used to construct a virus-like particle vaccine, which can be produced at high yield and at low cost. This protein can also be used to generate a subunit vaccine, which can be produced at high yield and at low cost.

We show that the zebrafish homolog of human ALK, DrLtk, is activated by the zebrafish ALKALs. This finding is of importance for understanding the role of ALK/LTK in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. We also show that the zebrafish ALKALs are required for the development of neural crest-derived tissues. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the involvement of ALK/LTK family receptors in neural crest development.

The emergence of Yersinia pestis, the causative agent of plague, is one of the most dramatic events in human history. However, the time of its origin and the nature of its progenitor remain unclear. We present a large dataset of ancient Y. pestis genomes from a wide geographic expanse across Eurasia, which allowed us to explore the diversity of the pathogen during the formative years of its evolution. Our results suggest that the pathogen was not a single lineage, but rather a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of Y. pestis in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of Y. pestis. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. (Less)

This work examined the extent to which men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—predicted support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. HM was also associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia. These findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. (PsycINFO Database Record

The agricultural management of grasslands and croplands has been shown to have a profound effect on the global carbon cycle. However, the effects of agricultural management on soil carbon in the context of the agricultural landscape are not well understood. We show that the management of croplands and grasslands in a landscape context can have a significant effect on soil carbon. We also show that the effects of management on soil carbon are not uniform across the landscape. This information is critical for understanding the effects of agricultural management on the carbon cycle and for developing strategies to mitigate climate change.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and spread to humans. We used this framework to identify the top 12 wildlife viruses with the greatest spillover potential, which included SARS-CoV-2. The SpillOver platform is a living, interactive database that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. We hope that this tool will be used to improve our understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans and to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is an important trait that can attract pollinators, but the chemical basis for this trait is poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the distantly related and hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a common trait that is likely to be favored by natural selection. This work also highlights the importance of studying the chemical basis for the evolution of color in nature.

The genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 500 and 700 AD. Our data indicate that the genetic ancestry of the men is mostly of northern and central European origin, while the women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. Our results provide insights into the genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period and suggest that the complex demographic processes occurring during this time contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings are important for understanding the origins of MERS-CoV and for developing strategies to prevent future bat-to-human transmissions. (Show more)

We describe the use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate a large cohort of febrile patients in Cambodia. We found that vector-borne pathogens were the most common clinical category, and that the most common pathogen was dengue virus. We also found that the use of metagenomic sequencing can identify zoonotic pathogens, such as Plasmodium knowlesi, and emerging pathogens, such as chikungunya virus. This study demonstrates the feasibility of using metagenomic sequencing to investigate undifferentiated febrile illness in resource-scarce settings, and the potential for this approach to be used to monitor the pathogen landscape in these settings. This approach can be used to identify the most common pathogens, as well as emerging pathogens, and can be used to monitor the pathogen landscape in resource-scarce settings. This information can be used to inform public health response. (PsycINFO Database Record

The human genome is replicated in a single-stranded template mode, which is a unique feature among the major organisms. This mode of replication is achieved by the lagging strand synthesis, which is performed by the DNA polymerase δ (pol δ). The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. However, the stability of the human pol δ holoenzyme is unknown. We designed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Surprisingly, the results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique insight into the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications on the single-stranded template mode of DNA synthesis. It also provides a foundation for future studies on the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme in other organisms.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, it has been possible to evolve ribozymes that can replicate RNA, but it has not been possible to evolve a ribozyme that can replicate RNA and synthesize functional RNA molecules. Here, we report the successful evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize functional RNA molecules and replicate RNA. This work represents a major step toward the creation of a functional RNA world in the laboratory.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also provide a new method for monitoring the physical appearance of neighborhoods over time. This method can be used to monitor the effects of urban revitalization efforts and to study the physical dynamics of cities.

COVID-19 is a highly infectious disease, and the mortality rate is high. The treatment of severe and critical patients is difficult. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which is a monoclonal antibody targeting IL-6, can improve the clinical outcome immediately in severe and critical COVID-19 patients. This study provides a new treatment for severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but it is also a highly toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The ability of fungi to control copper levels in the cell is important for their health and survival. We report the discovery of a fungal natural product, xanthocillin, that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. This discovery has implications for the role of natural products in fungal physiology and interactions with competing microbes.

The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary deposit on Mars is a significant discovery. Tridymite is a high-temperature (>870 °C) phase, and the deposit in which it was found is a sedimentary mudstone. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary deposit on Mars is a significant discovery.

The impact of late-spring frosts on plants and animals is a major concern for agriculture, forestry, and wildlife management. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and that the resistance strategies of trees are also changing in response. Our findings have implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental origins of these cells are unknown. Here we show that Th17 cells can give rise to cells with a Th1-like phenotype, and that these cells are critical for the development of colitis. These results have implications for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease, as they suggest that targeting both Th17 and Th1 cells may be a more effective approach to treatment than targeting Th17 cells alone.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living ALS patients, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and identify therapeutic targets.

The gut microbiota of the vector is a critical determinant of the pathogen’s ability to complete its life cycle. In this study, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and enhances the ability of the pathogen to complete its life cycle. We demonstrate that the protein binds to the bacterial cell wall, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the molecular mechanisms by which pathogens influence the gut microbiota of their vector and may have implications for the development of vector control strategies. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The short-tailed bird group is a major evolutionary lineage that is critical for understanding the origin of the modern avian bauplan. However, the currently known diversity of early branching short-tailed birds obscures our understanding of this major transition in avian evolution. Here, we describe a basal short-tailed bird, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This discovery adds important information about the evolution of the avian tail and the origin of the modern avian bauplan.

We show that the water vapor in the stratosphere increases with tropospheric temperature, implying that the water vapor in the stratosphere plays a role in the climate system. We estimate the strength of this feedback to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. This feedback is positive, meaning that it amplifies the warming of the climate system.

The evolution of color in animals is one of the most remarkable features of the animal kingdom. In this study, we show that the occurrence of high biliverdin in anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and relies on the same mechanism—the presence of a class of serpin family proteins that bind biliverdin. Our results present molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. We also provide a new perspective on the evolution of color in animals. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a feature of many solid tumors, and is associated with the maintenance of the stemness of cancer cells. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn induces expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. We also show that ALKBH5 expression is required for the maintenance of the stemness of breast cancer cells in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. These findings have implications for the treatment of breast cancer, as they suggest that targeting ALKBH5 may be a strategy for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. It is also one of the most fragile. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method for identifying the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality

The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is unknown, but the timing of the event, the carbon cycle response, and the rate of recovery are all critical to understanding the nature of the trigger and kill mechanisms. We present a precise age model for the extinction and recovery, which will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. This work will also establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. This work is a significant contribution to the field and will have broad implications for understanding the evolution of life on Earth. (Less)

The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the gut microbiota. It is well known that the intestinal epithelium is the main site of immune response in the body. However, the immune response in the intestine is complex and involves various cell types, including immune cells, epithelial cells, and fibroblasts. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays a crucial role in the intestinal epithelium. RORα deficiency leads to excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Our study provides a new perspective on the role of RORα in intestinal inflammation and may provide a new therapeutic target for inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for the COVID-19 pandemic, is the target of the majority of neutralizing antibodies. The D614G mutation in the spike protein is the most common mutation in the virus and is thought to increase infectivity. We have determined the structure of the spike protein in the D614G mutant and show that the mutant spike is more open and can adopt a range of different conformations. These results suggest that the D614G mutation may not increase infectivity and may instead facilitate the binding of the virus to its receptor. This may have important implications for vaccine design. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We project that the pandemic will result in a decline in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, the largest decline since 2003, and a decline in life expectancy at age 65 y of 0.87 y, the largest decline since 2005. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections highlight the need for urgent action to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 and to address the structural inequalities that have increased risk of exposure and mortality for Black and Latino Americans.

The chemical properties of matter are the basis of chemistry, and they are the result of the interplay between the properties of the atoms that make up matter and the interactions between them. In this work, we show that the properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we show that this is the result of s-d orbital transfer. We also show that the properties of the elements change with pressure, and we show that the properties of the elements can be predicted from the properties of the atoms.

We show that human ignitions and fire suppression have been the dominant drivers of changes in fire activity over the past century. However, climate change has also played a role, warming the world and increasing the likelihood of extreme fire weather. We find that climate–carbon cycle feedbacks, as caused by changing fire regimes, are most effective at slowing global warming under lower emission scenarios. Our study highlights that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems. Our results have implications for climate policy, as well as for the management of fire-dependent ecosystems.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a common feature of animal-microbe interactions. However, the mechanisms by which the host controls the activity of the symbionts are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, through the strategic provision of a single glycan, chitin. We show that the glycan is provided in a timed fashion, and that its catabolism is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This work provides a new perspective on the role of nutrients in the regulation of symbiosis, and suggests that the provision of specific nutrients may be a general strategy used by hosts to control the activity of their symbionts. (Show more)

We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We show how to represent documents as sequences of topics, and how to identify the gender bias of topics. Our method is flexible and broadly applicable, and can be extended to other domains. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We believe that this method will be of interest to researchers in many fields, including psychology, sociology, criminology, and medicine.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague, and on the role of climate in the spread of infectious diseases. It also provides a framework for the study of other diseases, and of the history of climate and society

Asteroids are a group of marine invertebrates that are of economic and ecological importance. In the last 2 y, a disease has been observed in populations of asteroids on the Pacific Coast of North America. The disease is characterized by rapid mortality, behavioral changes, lesions, loss of turgor, limb autotomy, and death. We show that the disease is caused by a densovirus. The virus is transmitted by the starfish Asterias rubens, which is a common predator of asteroids. The virus is present in the plankton, sediments, and in nonasteroid echinoderms, suggesting that it can spread over long distances. The virus has been present in museum specimens of asteroids for at least 72 y, indicating that it has been present on the North American Pacific Coast for a long time. This study provides evidence that a virus is responsible for the mass mortality of asteroids.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a heterogeneous disease with a poor prognosis. We have previously shown that a monoclonal antibody targeting interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is able to target AML stem cells in xenograft models. Here, we show that this antibody is able to target AML stem cells in patients, and that it is able to target primary AML cells in vitro. We also show that the antibody is able to target primary AML cells in vivo. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study also provides a proof of principle for the use of this antibody in the treatment of AML in humans.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, which allowed us to study the genetic history of the island in a fine-grained way. We find that Madagascar was settled by a Bantu and Austronesian population, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history of Madagascar is relatively recent, and the genetic structure is influenced by geography, with a few centuries being sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide insights into the settlement history of Madagascar and the genetic consequences of the colonization of the island. They also provide a framework to study the genetic consequences of the recent colonization of the island.

Bacteria use small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that interacts with a membrane-bound enzyme and increases its activity. We found that the protein interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress two other genes. The protein and RNA compete for the same binding site on the target genes, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This is an example of a protein that has evolved to interfere with the ability of an sRNA to regulate its target genes. This is an example of a protein that has evolved to interfere with the ability of an sRNA to regulate its target genes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Less)

Crop experts are the primary source of information on the status of crops in the US. However, the information they provide is qualitative and subjective, and is not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We show how to convert the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We also show that the resulting index is able to provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of using crop expert assessments to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. This approach can be extended to other crops and countries, and can be used to monitor the status of other agricultural commodities such as livestock, fisheries, and forestry. This will be key to monitor the impact of climate change and other environmental and economic factors on agricultural production.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be based on the integration of information over time. Here we propose a model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of single neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind information over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind information over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The soil is a major carbon reservoir, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community. In this study, we provide a synthesis of the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. (Less)

The evolution of the plastid genome is a unique window into the history of life on Earth. It is also a model system for the study of the molecular evolution of the genome as a whole. Here, we present a model of the trajectory of the plastid genome during the evolution of parasitic lifestyles. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on the plastid genome in a stepwise manner. Our findings have implications for the evolution of the genome as a whole and for the study of the molecular evolution of the genome as a whole.

The 2015–2017 drought in southwestern South Africa was the result of a combination of natural and anthropogenic factors. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the drought by a factor of five to six. This result is important for the understanding of the drought risk in SSA and for the design of adaptation strategies. The results also highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk to future anthropogenic emissions.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major advance in the field of materials science. However, the conditions under which they are formed are still poorly understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this material, which is the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal, provides a unique link between the past and the present, and it is a reminder of the importance of the Trinity test in the history of nuclear weapons.

Photosynthesis is the most important biological process on Earth. It is powered by light, which is converted to chemical energy. The light reaction is the site of this conversion, and it is dependent on the capture of light energy by the chlorophyll pigments. The chlorophyll pigments are modified by a series of reactions that are catalyzed by enzymes that are unique to each pigment. The enzymes that are responsible for the formation of the chlorophyll pigments are the most productive biological pathways on Earth.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as EAE. Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1, which is known to be involved in the pathogenesis of neurodegenerative diseases. In this study, we found that ASK1 plays a critical role in the development of EAE, and that ASK1 is required for the development of neuroinflammation in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes. Our findings suggest that ASK1 may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a better understanding of the role of ASK1 in the development of EAE. (PsycINFO Database Record

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and now includes the lowest calendar-year and 12-mo precipitation, the highest annual temperature, and the most extreme drought indicators on record. The extremely warm and dry conditions have led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that precipitation deficits in California were more than twice as likely to yield drought years if they occurred when conditions were warm. We also find that although there has not been a substantial change in the probability of either negative or moderately negative precipitation anomalies in recent decades, the occurrence of drought years has been greater in the past two decades than in the preceding century. Finally, we conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and may facilitate the development of new therapeutic approaches. (PsycINFO Database Record
This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but it also highlights the potential for more positive content.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. In this study, we identify mutations in STIM1 and ORAI1 that result in a spectrum of phenotypes, including congenital miosis, tubular aggregate myopathy, and bleeding diathesis. Our findings expand our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. This study also provides a framework for the development of new therapies for patients with other diseases that are associated with dysregulated CRAC channel signaling. (PsycINFO Database Record

The spread of protein aggregates throughout the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease to study the spread of aggregates in the brain. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We demonstrate that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, showing that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in the brain and may help to identify potential therapeutic targets for neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system and the potential for MTX to be used as a therapeutic agent. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth, and one of the most common genetic alterations in cancer cells is the loss of function of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). We have developed a series of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT, and have shown that they are effective in blocking the growth of colon cancer xenografts. We have also shown that the one-carbon donor formate can rescue cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. Our work provides a rationale for the use of SHMT inhibitors in the treatment of cancer, and in particular, in the treatment of lymphoma.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. The disease is caused by mutations in a variety of proteins, including superaggregation-prone proteins such as SOD1, TDP-43, and FUS. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Instead, the inclusions are caused by a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state is likely to be the result of a combination of factors, including the presence of a toxic species, the presence of a stress response, and the presence of a stress response regulator. Our results suggest that the metastable state is a common feature of proteins that are prone to aggregation, and that this metastable state may be a key factor in the pathogenesis of ALS and other neurodegenerative diseases.

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The study of the early evolution of angiosperms is of great interest to the scientific community. The study of the evolution of aquatic plants is of even greater interest, as they are among the most ancient plants and are of great importance in the present. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous, is of particular interest, as it is the oldest known aquatic angiosperm.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in biology, and it is of great interest to understand the evolution of the human pathogen B19V. We present 10 ancient B19V genomes, which are ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years old, and we show that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 thousand years old. We also show that the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 thousand years ago. These results show that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time and that the evolution of B19V is slower than previously thought. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Less)

We show that the acceleration of global mean sea level over the last 25 y is not due to increased ocean heat uptake but rather to the combined effects of climate change and the natural variability of the climate system.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States for all adults, but that pain has increased more for those born after 1950 than for those born before 1950. This pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. Instead, it fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If this trend continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The structure and dynamics of enzyme active sites are of fundamental importance to understanding the function of enzymes. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically characterized picture of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. This integrated approach provides insight into the chemical dynamics of the active site, including the protonation states of the cofactor, substrate, and catalytic side chains, as well as the location and orientation of crystallographic waters within the active site. This detailed picture of the intermediate, including the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state, is key to understanding the reaction mechanism. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of enzyme active sites. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific antiviral treatment for MERS, and the high mortality rate of the disease stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. We show that remdesivir, an antiviral drug that was shown to be effective against Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)-CoV, is also effective against MERS-CoV in a nonhuman primate model. This suggests that remdesivir may be a useful treatment for MERS, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a common feature of animal-microbe interactions. However, the mechanisms by which the host controls the activity of the symbionts are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, through the provision of a single glycan, chitin. We show that the glycan is provided in a specific manner, at a specific time, and in a specific quantity, and that the glycan is required for the persistence of the symbionts. These results suggest that the provision of nutrients may be a general mechanism by which hosts control the activities of their symbionts. This mechanism may be particularly important in the context of the dynamic changes that occur in the symbiotic relationship between the host and its microbiota during the maturation of the symbiosis. (Show more)

This research has implications for the design of effective interventions to reduce suspension rates, which are a major driver of the school-to-prison pipeline. It also has implications for the design of interventions to improve the quality of teacher–student relationships, which are a major driver of student achievement.

DNA alkylation is one of the major causes of DNA damage. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on the transcription process. We found that the transcription process is sensitive to the EtdT lesions, and the transcription stalling and mutagenesis are dependent on the regioisomeric EtdT lesions. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. These findings are expected to provide important information for the development of novel therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe pneumonia. To better understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. These findings may help to guide the development of effective vaccines and antiviral therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental problems. In the UK, 51% of greenhouse gas emissions come from food production and consumption. In the US, 32% of greenhouse gas emissions come from food production and consumption. In both countries, the food system is responsible for a large proportion of land use and water consumption, and for biodiversity loss. In the UK, 21% of greenhouse gas emissions come from the production of animal feed. In the US, 31% of greenhouse gas emissions come from animal agriculture. We show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large university cafeteria by 50% led to a proportional increase in vegetarian meal sales of 78.8%. This is equivalent to a proportional increase in vegetarian meal sales of 40.8% in the quartile of diners with the lowest levels of vegetarian meal selection. This is a simple and effective way to make a large contribution to environmental sustainability.

The cell surface proteome, the surfaceome, is the interface for engaging the extracellular space in normal and cancer cells. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. Addition of a potent MEK inhibitor that blocks MAPK signaling brings each oncogene-induced surfaceome back to a common state reflecting the strong dependence of the oncogene on the MAPK pathway to propagate signaling. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal costs and that it is unlikely to have significant effects on electoral outcomes.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global population. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein, which is proposed to interfere with the host immune response. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. This work provides a better understanding of the molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease, and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major risk factor for cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats, and that this is mediated by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε, and to an up-regulation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1). These findings provide a molecular basis for the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia. They also suggest that CRFR1 antagonists may be useful in the treatment of cerebral edema in hypoxia. This study may also have implications for the understanding of the development of cerebral edema in other conditions, such as brain trauma. (PsycINFO Database Record

We live in an era of big data. The size of the data sets is growing rapidly, and the sophistication of the statistical methods used to analyze them is growing even faster. This paper describes a new challenge that arises in this setting. We have a large data set, and we want to find the strongest associations that it contains. The fact that we have searched for the strongest associations means that we must set a higher bar for declaring significant an association that we find. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. Our goal is to help the reader understand the nature of the challenge and to provide a sense of the power of modern statistical methods. We do not claim that our examples are the only possible applications of selective inference. We also do not claim that our examples are the best possible. We hope that the reader will find the examples interesting and will be motivated to explore further applications of selective inference in the context of big data.

The development of vascular ECs is a critical step in the formation of blood vessels. However, the development of ECs is difficult to achieve in vitro, and the formation of blood vessels in vivo is also difficult to achieve in vivo. Therefore, the development of ECs and the formation of blood vessels in vivo are still challenging. In this study, we found that the transcription factor ETV2 can induce the development of ECs in vitro and in vivo. This study provides a new method for the development of ECs and the formation of blood vessels in vivo. It is expected that this study will contribute to the treatment of vascular diseases. (Show more)

We report the discovery of a third class of RTKs, the augmentors, and their physiological ligands. We show that augmentors are essential for the development of iridophores, a unique type of photoreceptor that is found in the zebrafish eye and in the skin of some fish species.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. In this study, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function and insulin secretion. Our findings provide a new perspective for understanding the molecular basis of T2D and suggest that STING might be a potential target for the treatment of T2D.

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza and are responsible for occasional pandemics. They are able to infect a wide range of species, including humans, and are therefore a major threat to public health. The influenza A virus genome is segmented into eight fragments, which is an evolutionary advantage. However, it also complicates the packaging of the genome, which is necessary for the production of infectious virions. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments, which is required for optimal viral replication. This interaction is sequence specific and not widely conserved among influenza A viruses. Our results indicate that the interaction between viral RNA segments is a key step in the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. This mechanism might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our findings are important for understanding the molecular mechanisms of influenza A virus replication and evolution. They also provide a basis for the development of antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in the arterial wall. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of factors. In this study, we found that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by disturbed flow is a critical event in the development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the natural and human landscape for millennia. However, in recent decades, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially. Climate change has likely contributed to some of the increase in wildfire activity, but the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Our results highlight the importance of human activities in increasing the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and the need to consider the role of people in reducing wildfire risk.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also provide a new method for monitoring the physical appearance of neighborhoods over time. This method can be used to monitor the effects of urban revitalization efforts and to study the spatial dynamics of urban change.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecofriendly pest control method. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the time between cell infection and viral production is short, the rate of viral production is rapid, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is long. We also show that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can reduce the peak median viral load and shorten the time to undetectable median viral load, whereas treatment given 2 d postinfection is mostly ineffective in accelerating plasma viral load loss. These results can be used to guide the development of effective treatment strategies for ZIKV. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on the planet. However, they are threatened by a variety of environmental stressors, including climate change. In the context of global warming, the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is one of the most feared consequences of mass bleaching events. We show that the metabolic and molecular responses of the coral host to heat stress are driven by altered nutrient cycling, which in turn is a consequence of the heat stress-induced metabolic stress. Our findings provide insights into the stability of the coral–algal symbiosis and may help us to understand the mechanisms underlying the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis in the context of climate change. This may ultimately help us to develop strategies for reef conservation.

The intestinal epithelium is the main barrier between the host and the external environment. In the presence of tumors, the intestinal epithelium is exposed to a dysbiotic microbiome, which can lead to barrier dysfunction. Here, we show that the microbiome can trigger a regenerative response in the tumor-bearing intestine, which in turn can stimulate tumor growth. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our findings have implications for the treatment of cancer, as well as for the development of new strategies to control the intestinal microbiome. They also provide a mechanistic framework for the development of new therapies for cancer and intestinal infections.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients do not respond to chemotherapy. In this study, we found that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, which enhanced the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer.

The timing of the onset of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is one of the most debated aspects of the last deglaciation. We show that the onset of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is linked to a series of volcanic eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a poleward shift of the Southern Hemisphere westerlies.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which is the first of its kind. Our data reveal that inland fisheries are a major source of animal protein for the poor and undernourished, and that they are particularly important in regions where alternative sources of nutrition and employment are scarce. However, the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our data can be used to identify areas where inland fisheries are most likely to contribute to food security and biodiversity conservation. This information can be integrated into environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the Mo-based oxide are the key to achieve high capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This work is expected to be a milestone in the field of aqueous Li-ion batteries. The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery has implications for understanding the molecular mechanisms that control the regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system.

The process of meiosis is essential for the production of genetically diverse gametes, which are necessary for sexual reproduction. In flowering plants, meiosis is a complex process that involves the formation of chiasmata, which are the sites of genetic exchange. The strength of chiasmata is determined by the rate of crossovers, which is in turn determined by the rate of recombination. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination events in the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that the distribution of recombination events is similar to that in yeast and in mice, suggesting that the process of recombination in flowering plants may have been conserved over time. This study provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular mechanisms of recombination in flowering plants. (Show more)

The brain is a dynamic organ, and the study of its resting state is a fundamental step in understanding its organization and function. We have developed a method to measure the brain’s resting state by combining functional MRI and metabolic imaging. This method provides a direct measure of the brain’s resting organization, which can be used to study the brain in health and disease. We have applied this method to Parkinson’s disease, Alzheimer’s disease, and healthy subjects, and we have found that the brain’s resting state is a dynamic property that can be used to study the progression of these diseases.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA that regulates translation. We show that a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap, is also found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. This finding raises the possibility that the NAD+ cap could regulate mRNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs.

The epigenetic regulation of gene expression is a key mechanism for the maintenance of the metabolic memory observed in people with diabetes after intensive vs. conventional therapy during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT). We show that DNA methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years after the end of the DCCT and are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory and provide a basis for future studies to investigate the role of DNA methylation in the maintenance of the beneficial effects of intensive therapy.

This study provides a deeper understanding of the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). Our findings may aid in the design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disease that is characterized by a high mortality rate. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a possible explanation for the high mortality rate of alcohol dependence and suggests that the gut microbiota may be a promising target for the management of this disease. The tomato is one of the most important crops in the world, and its flavor is a major contributor to its popularity. The flavor of tomato fruit is the result of a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the role of the genes involved in their production is unclear. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also show that this gene is required for the production of a wide range of nitrogenous volatiles in Nicotiana benthamiana, providing a model for further studies. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor. (Less)

We show that the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning are dependent on the thermal tolerance traits of the species present in the community. We demonstrate that the presence of species with thermal tolerance traits that are outside the range of ambient conditions will increase the resilience of the community to warming. This is important because the majority of species in most ecosystems are not adapted to the current range of environmental conditions. Our results have important implications for our understanding of the impacts of climate change on biodiversity and ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation, and its function is thought to be based on the activity of grid, head-direction (HD), border, and object-vector (OV) cells. However, the anatomical organization of these cell types is still unclear. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in MEC during free-running behavior. Our data show that grid cells are strongly coupled among themselves, while border, HD, and OV cells tend to intermingle. These results suggest that grid cells might be largely distinct from those of border, HD, and OV cells, and that grid cells exhibit strong coupling among themselves but weaker links to other cell types. This study provides a new approach for understanding the organization of the MEC. It also provides a platform for future studies of the function of the MEC. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT, which is known to be a key regulator of flowering in plants, is also able to induce flowering in the parasitic plant Cuscuta australis. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also shows that the FT gene in dodder is not able to function in flowering induction. This finding is important for understanding the evolution of flowering in plants and the evolution of parasitic behavior in plants. It also provides a model system for studying the evolution of flowering and flowering regulation. It is likely that the FT gene is not the only flowering regulator in dodder.
